item.title: A.I. Is on Its Way to Something Even More Remarkable Than Intelligence
item.description: Skeptics overlook how our concepts change.

item.title: Trumpism Will Be With Us for a Very Long Time
item.description: Why the future of the G.O.P. will likely be guided by the right’s political DNA.

item.title: Trump Was Never a Kingmaker. Are Republicans Finally Seeing It?
item.description: The round table convenes to discuss what comes after the Democrats’ big wins — and whether the “red hat” coalition can recover.

item.title: What if the Monarchy Went Out With a Bang?
item.description: If all other institutions fail, is there not a certain unique potency in the monarchy before dissolution?

item.title: We Can’t Pretend to Know the Future of the Democratic Party
item.description: There is no one-size-fits-all template for winning elections.

item.title: Bruce Springsteen’s Father Complicates a Powerful American Narrative
item.description: He had a good factory job that helped him raise a family. But it didn’t save him from despair.

item.title: Why Is Trump So Afraid of American Voters?
item.description: President Trump raged after Democrats won multiple elections this week. And now he’s calling on lawmakers to take action: To do more gerrymandering, to outlaw mail-in ballots and to make voter ID laws more strict. Why is Trump so afraid of American voters? He’s afraid of losing his majority in the midterm elections, argues Times Opinion editor Kathleen Kingsbury.

item.title: Trump Aid Cuts Kill More Christians Than Jihadists Do
item.description: Murderous attacks on Christians and Muslims alike are a real problem in Nigeria. Cutting humanitarian assistance there is even more lethal.

item.title: Trump’s Dismantling of Our Democracy
item.description: Readers respond to a Times editorial detailing the country’s slide toward autocracy.

item.title: Are Post-Trump Politics Emerging?
item.description: The round table convenes to discuss what comes after the Democrats’ big wins — and whether the “red hat” coalition can recover.

item.title: Exercising Is the Worst
item.description: Exercise has never been fun, but our expectations for physical performance, what it means to be healthy, and what it means to age have gotten too high.

item.title: The Election Victories Democrats Can Learn the Most From
item.description: The constructive, if messy, path forward is for the party to embrace an all-of-the-above approach.

item.title: Will Hamas Lay Down Its Arms?
item.description: For a movement that built its legitimacy around what it called resistance, giving up its weapons is not just a tactical concession, it is an existential unraveling.

item.title: Just How Bad Was Trump’s Very Bad Night?
item.description: Ezra Klein and Aaron Retica discuss whether affordability is the Democrats’ winning message, Trump’s politics of cruelty and how liberalism can win right now.

item.title: The New Obama Musical Is No ‘Hamilton’
item.description: But it’s still history.

item.title: Explaining Zohran Mamdani’s Win in New York City
item.description: A triumph in New York City has a lesson for the Democrats

item.title: More Democrats Need to Follow Pelosi’s Example and Retire
item.description: She has shown herself more willing than most to put aside her own ego for the greater good.

item.title: ‘Nothing Is Forever in Politics’: 3 Writers on the Collapse of the Trump Coalition
item.description: What both parties should take away from a night of Democratic victories.

item.title: Trump Is Resurrecting the Gatsby Era. The Hangover Could Be Brutal.
item.description: Donald Trump’s recent Gatsby party encapsulates this moment of economic peril.

item.title: How to Be a Good Citizen When Your Country Does Bad Things
item.description: Is it possible to be a good citizen in a country that does bad things? In this video, New York Times Opinion columnist M. Gessen argues yes — and introduces Israeli dissidents who show us how.

item.title: Goodbye, Andrew Cuomo
item.description: He’s sharp-elbowed, retributive and transactional, and won’t be missed.

item.title: Mamdani’s Victory Is Less Significant Than You Think
item.description: New York’s next mayor won’t save the Democrats.

item.title: Imagining What’s in Trump’s Brain
item.description: Inside the minds of authoritarians.

item.title: What Started as Affordability Politics Has Become Something Deeper
item.description: Zohran Mamdani’s campaign ended up winning over some of the exact voters who make up a major part of the Democratic coalition. Why is worth considering.

item.title: Will the Idea of America Be Lost?
item.description: Readers discuss equal opportunity and immigration as central ideas in the American project. Also: The value of brain research; Democratic momentum.

item.title: The Supreme Court’s Gender Passport Ruling Isn’t About ID
item.description: And it defeats the basic purpose of the document.

item.title: What Is ‘Toxic Femininity’?
item.description: Gossip and conflict avoidance may be a sign that a workplace has become overly feminized, Helen Andrews argues on this week’s “Interesting Times.” In this episode, she and the author Leah Libresco Sargeant debate what institutions lose when they shift from male to female dominance.

item.title: Have ‘Feminine Vices’ Taken Over the Workplace?
item.description: What are “feminine virtues” and “feminine vices”? On “Interesting Times,” the Opinion columnist Ross Douthat moderates a debate between Helen Andrews, the author of the recent essay “The Great Feminization,” and Leah Libresco Sargeant, the author of “The Dignity of Dependence,” about the impact these virtues and vices may have on the workplace.

item.title: Challenges and Cheers for Bill Gates on Climate Change
item.description: Readers respond to news and opinion articles about Bill Gates’s public memo on climate change. Also: Interfaith connections; the myth of originalism.

item.title: Why It Will Be Hard for Five Justices to Bless Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: The problem with giving any president basically unconstrained authority to raise revenue via tariffs.

item.title: Nancy Pelosi Retires as a Master of Congress
item.description: She’ll rightly be lionized as the first woman speaker, but in one sense, that was the most incidental of her myriad accomplishments.

item.title: I Photographed an Appalachian Family for 15 Years
item.description: A photographer spends 15 years documenting an Appalachian family and the constant pressure of poverty in their lives.

item.title: Guillermo del Toro’s ‘Frankenstein’ Asks Us to Consider the Monster
item.description: Has “Frankenstein” become all feelings and no blood?

item.title: Unearthing the Lost Music of Broadway
item.description: Some of the best music I’ve ever heard was almost lost forever.

item.title: Trump Is Always Teaching Us About the Constitution
item.description: Where is the line between authority and authoritarianism?

item.title: The Indispensable Erdogan
item.description: Western capitals should be wary of treating democracy in Turkey as a luxury rather than a necessity.

item.title: Mamdani’s Victory Is Less Significant Than You Think
item.description: Does Zohran Mamdani’s win mean a new dawn for the Democratic Party? Not exactly, Ross Douthat argues. In this mini-episode of “Interesting Times,” Ross explains that the New York mayor’s office has historically been a “springboard to nowhere,” rather than a precursor for national politics.

item.title: Did Liberal Feminism Ruin the Workplace?
item.description: And if so, can conservative feminism fix it?

item.title: Sudan Is in Free Fall
item.description: The slaughter in Darfur could potentially be stopped, if those with leverage chose to act.

item.title: Make No Mistake: Trump Is an Albatross
item.description: Just Ask Mikie Sherrill, Abigail Spanberger and Zohran Mamdani.

item.title: 6 Ways Zohran Mamdani Can Improve New York City
item.description: Mamdani, who campaigned on sweeping promises, can build a positive legacy by focusing on tangible accomplishments.

item.title: For Gen Z-ers, Work Is Now More Depressing Than Unemployment
item.description: Technology has left them with little autonomy or security in their jobs.

item.title: Mamdani’s Win and a Spark for Democrats
item.description: Readers react to strong election results for Democrats. Also: the case against gerrymandering.

item.title: How Should Trump Approach China? A Debate.
item.description: Two economists on the price of playing nice with a superpower.

item.title: Do Dumb Ideas Ever Die?
item.description: Unlike old soldiers, they don’t even fade away.

item.title: The Tragedy of Dick Cheney
item.description: He tried to warn Americans about Trump, but they had already learned not to believe him.

item.title: What Conservatives Should Do About Nick Fuentes
item.description: There are no shortcuts in the fight against right-wing antisemitism.

item.title: It Would Be Trump’s Honor to Pay for Food Stamps
item.description: When Republicans sing Kumbaya.

item.title: In Search of the Great Literary Novel
item.description: Readers respond to a guest essay about the continuing vitality of literary fiction. Also: Exxon vs. California; a Supreme Court split on tactics.
